questions.question_text: What are two functions of IKEv1 but not IKEv2? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
B. With IKEv1, aggressive mode negotiates faster than main mode.
E. With IKEv1, when using aggressive mode, the initiator and responder identities are passed in cleartext.

Explanation:

B. In IKEv1, aggressive mode negotiates faster than main mode because it requires fewer messages to establish the IKE SA (Security Association). However, aggressive mode in IKEv1 has been identified as less secure than main mode because it is more susceptible to attacks.

E. With IKEv1, when using aggressive mode, the initiator and responder identities are passed in cleartext, which can potentially expose sensitive information. In IKEv2, the identities are protected by encryption, providing an additional layer of security.

Selected Answer: BE

What is the most commonly used protocol for network telemetry?

comments.content: This is correct. Go search Netflow vs SNMP and you'll see that SNMP is not considered telemetry.

discussion.content: I think this is tricky. I vote for A (Netflow), because I think that SNMP is NOT considered a Network Telemetry element and Netflow is

Selected Answer: A
Going with A for the reasons Fuku mentioned. SNMP is not technically a network telemetry gathering protocol. it gives stats about a device itself. It can not determine the health/state of an actual network as a whole. Even if you have SNMP on 10 devices versus NETFLOW on 10 devices... you will have much better readings from NETFLOW than you ever could with SNMP.
B , keyword " most commonly used protocol"

I vote A because NetFlow = Cisco
This is a Cisco exam...

A and B are correct.
https://www.cisco.com/c/en/us/solutions/collateral/enterprise/design-zone-security/telemetry-architecture-guide.html

Selected Answer: B
The most commonly used protocol for network telemetry is Simple Network Management Protocol (SNMP). SNMP is an Internet Standard protocol used to manage and monitor network devices, such as routers, switches, servers, and printers. It provides a way to collect and organize information about network devices and their performance, and to send that information to management systems for analysis and reporting. SNMP allows administrators to monitor and manage network devices from a central location, and to quickly identify and troubleshoot issues before they affect the network's performance or availability

B - https://www.techtarget.com/searchnetworking/definition/streaming-network-telemetry
SNMP. Prior to streaming network telemetry technologies, the simple network monitoring protocol (SNMP) was the standard method for collecting network telemetry information

Selected Answer: CE
APEX licensing is required for 802.1x and Posturing. But it isn't a component.

Selected Answer: CE
Answer is C and E
The two Cisco ISE components that enforce security policies on noncompliant endpoints by blocking network access are profiling and posture agents.

Profiling is the process of identifying the type of device that is attempting to connect to the network. This is done by analyzing the device's MAC address, IP address, and other characteristics. Once the device has been profiled, it can be assigned to a specific security policy.

Posture agents are software that is installed on endpoints. They monitor the endpoint's security posture and report back to ISE. If the endpoint is found to be noncompliant, ISE can block its access to the network.

Selected Answer: CE
C and E. This is not a licensing exam so not going with A

What is a difference between DMVPN and sVTI?

choices.A: DMVPN provides interoperability with other vendors, whereas sVTI does not.
choices.C: DMVPN supports dynamic tunnel establishment, whereas sVTI does not.
choices.D: DMVPN supports tunnel encryption, whereas sVTI does not.
choices.B: DMVPN supports static tunnel establishment, whereas sVTI does not.

discussion.content:
Answer is C.

DMVPN supports dynamic tunnel establishment, allowing spokes to dynamically build tunnels between each other without requiring a direct tunnel to be statically configured between every pair of spokes.

On the other hand, Static Virtual Tunnel Interfaces (sVTI) involve manually configuring the tunnel endpoints and do not provide dynamic tunnel establishment. sVTI is typically used when a static point-to-point tunnel needs to be established between two devices.

D for Dynamic and s for static

C. DMVPN supports dynamic tunnel establishment, whereas sVTI does not.
